abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Enhancing Agricultural
            Productivity Project (EAPP) for Kenya were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Grantee performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: in-country
            systems input distribution, agricultural credit;
            diversification support should adequately support emergency
            operations. In the future, more attention should be focused
            on appraising and supporting capacity building as an
            important success factor. The fiduciary management capacity
            of the implementing agency at the national and lower levels
            needs to be enhanced. There is need to adequately provide
            for capacity building of national and district level staff
            and to encourage computerization and simplification of most
            of the records. Inclusion of some critical post-harvest
            interventions can improve project outcomes. Whenever
            production-enhancing technologies are promoted, it is
            advisable to also support other off-farm activities such as
            storage and marketing. Cross-sectoral and international
            experience, especially in the input voucher scheme, should
            be incorporated. The Ministry of Agriculture (MoA) should
            emulate existing transfer mechanisms proven successful in
            Kenya. Existing programs provide useful platforms on which
            to build and gradually scale up service activities such as
            the ones pursued under this project. Overall, the EAPP was
            justified given the context of Kenyas import dependence and
            rising food and fuel prices.
